questions.text: An ICU patient who is dependant on oxygen support requires an MRI. What material is used to build the medical gas cylinder which can be used in this scenario?
questions.solution:
MRI compatible medical gas cylinders are made of aluminium, while most medical gas cylinders are constructed of molybdenum steel.

The cylinders are produced in various sizes designated by a capital letter code.

  • Size A is the smallest.
  • Size H is the largest.
  • Size E is the cylinder most commonly used in anesthesia machines, for patient transport, and resuscitation, followed by Size D. 
  • Size J is commonly used for cylinder manifold systems for central supply.

questions.text: Muscle relaxant to be avoided in a hypertensive patient?
questions.solution:
• Pancuronium is avoided in hypertensive patients because it causes vagal blockade and sympathetic stimulation.
  • Sympathetic stimulation is due to ganglionic stimulation, neural release of catecholamines and inhibition of reuptake of catecholamines. Hence It can aggravate hypertension.
  • But when it is used in small increments slowly, it doesn’t produce significant changes in heart rate and blood pressure.
  • For the same reason, it is to be cautiously used in patients with coronary artery disease, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and aortic stenosis.

questions.text: Flousol-DA is _______
questions.solution:
Flousol-DA is artificial whole blood.

There are two types of synthetic oxygen carrying substances (artificial whole blood)

  • Perfluorochemical emulsions: Examples: Flousol-DA, perfluoroocytl bromide, Oxygent, Oxycyte
  • Hemoglobin-based Oxygen carriers(HBOCs): PolyHeme

questions.text: For a patient with respiratory failure requiring controlled ventilation, which of the following is true about the order of efficiency of Mapleson circuits?
questions.solution:
From the above options, the order of efficiency of Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation is D=F>B>A. 

When the Mapleson D circuit is used for controlled ventilation, the fresh gas flow rate of the circuit is closest to the physiological minute ventilation of the patient.


 

Related Pearl: Mapleson Classification

Mapleson circuit   Other name  Fresh gas flow rate
Spontaneous ventilation  Controlled ventilation
A Magills 1 minute ventilation (MV) i.e. 80 ml/kg/min Very high and difficult to predict
B - 2-3× (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
C Water’s to and fro 2-3 × (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
D Bain circuit 2-3 × (MV) 1-2 × (MV)
E Ayre’s t-piece 2-3 × (MV) 3 × (MV)
F Jackson rees modification 2-3 × (MV) 2 × (MV)

 

Note:

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in spontaneous ventilation is  A > DFE > CB (A Dog Can Bite - Usually a spontaneous event)

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation is DFE > BC > A (Dead Babies can't assist - controlled)

questions.text: A patient is undergoing modified radical neck dissection (MRND) for laryngeal malignancy. While ligating the internal jugular vein, his etCO2 dropped from 40 mmHg to 14 mmHg, and the patient developed hypotension along with cardiac arrhythmia. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
A drastic fall in etCO2 with hypotension during neck surgery is most likely due to venous air embolism (VAE).

In modified radical neck dissection (MRND), a head-up position is given to provide a bloodless surgical field. VAE into severed vessels is likely to occur when the surgical site is above the right atrium and venous pressure at the incision site is below the atmospheric pressure. Pulmonary artery pressure will rise and etCO2 will fall after a venous air embolism.

In sympathetic overactivity and carotid body stimulation, blood pressure will rise.

In vagal stimulation, a drastic drop in etCO2 is unlikely.

 

This is a recent AIIMS question. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the most sensitive device for detecting intracardiac air embolus.

questions.text: You are a junior resident conducting research on the efficacy of different methods to monitor the depth of anaesthesia. Which of the following methods will be not be considered for evaluation in your research?
questions.solution:
Capnography is not considered as it cannot be used to monitor the depth of anaesthesia.

Capnography is a quantitative measure of end-tidal carbon dioxide that is used to assess ventilation in the perioperative period and confirm the correct placement of an endotracheal tube.

Monitors used to assess the depth of anaesthesia: 

  1. Electroencephalography (EEG)
  2. Bispectral index (BIS)
  3. Entropy
  4. Evoked responses (EP) - Motor EP, sensory EP (Auditory, visual, brain stem evoked potential)
  5. Patient state index
  6. Narcotrend.

questions.text: Opioid with highest water partition coefficient is ________
questions.solution:
Sufentanil has the highest water partition coefficient and hence is the most potent opioid.

Fentanyl is 100 times more potent and sufentanil is 1000 times more potent than morphine.

 

Octanol/ water partition coefficients of opioids

 

  • Octanol/water partition coefficient is a measure of the potency of a compound and the ability to traverse lipid membranes.
    • Morphine – 1.4
    • Remifentanil – 17.3
    • Alfentanil -145
    • Fentanyl – 813
    • Sufentanil-1778
  • As can be seen, sufentanil has the highest octanol/water partition coefficient making it the most potent opioid.

questions.text: DIBUCAINE NUMBER is used to assess:

choices.text: Genetic make up of an individual with respect to butyryl cholinesterase

questions.solution:
Dibucaine number indicates the genetic makeup of an individual with respect to butyrylcholinesterase, BUT it does not measure the concentration of the enzyme in the plasma substrate.

Dibucaine is a local anesthetic which measures pseudocholinesterase function but not the amount of enzyme.

It inhibits normal pseudocholinesterase activity by 80% but inhibits atypical enzyme activity by only 20%.

Dibucaine number refers to the percentage of inhibition of pseudocholinesterase activity.

A patient with normal pseudocholinesterase has a dibucaine number of 80; a homozygote will have a dibucaine number of 20.

Therefore, adequacy of pseudocholinesterase can be determined

  • quantitatively in units per liter (a minor factor) - in laboratory
  • qualitatively-by dibucaine number (the major factor)

Dibucaine number:

  • High dibucaine number (80) means high quantity of normal and low quantity of atypical
  • Pseudocholinesterase : normal response to succinyl choline and mivacurium.
  • Low dibucaine number (<30) means low quantity of normal and high quantity of atypical
  • Pseudocholinesterase : prolonged succinyl choline and mivacurium block.

questions.text: Water content of soda lime is ________.
questions.solution:
The water content of soda lime is 15%.

Dry CO2 absorbent (Baralyme > Sodalime) can produce carbon monoxide. 

The magnitude of CO production from greatest to least: Desflurane >= Enflurane > Isoflurane >> Halothane =Sevoflurane

Related Pearl: Composition of CO2 Absorbers in rebreathing system

  • Silica - 0.2%
  • Moisture-  14-19%

Granule size is 4-8 mesh

Absorbs up to 23L of CO2/100 g

questions.text: A poorly controlled diabetic with retinopathy would be placed under?
questions.solution:
ASA GRADE 3: Patient with severe systemic disease (some functional limitations)

  • Poorly controlled diabetes: Severe systemic disease
  • Retinopathy: Functional limitation due to poor vision or loss of vision

- American Society of Anesthesiologists’(ASA) classification is used to define relative risk prior to conscious sedation and surgical anesthesia.

- It is simple, reproducible and strongly correlates to perioperative risk

American Society of Anesthesiologists’ physical status classification of patients -  Class Definition

  • 1 Normal healthy patient
  • 2 Patient with mild systemic disease (no functional limitations)
  • 3 Patient with severe systemic disease (some functional limitations)
  • 4 Patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life (functionality incapacitated)
  • 5 A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation
  • 6 A brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes

 

Related Pearl: American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status Classification of Patients

American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status (ASA-PS) classification is used to define relative risk before conscious sedation and surgical anaesthesia and strongly correlates to perioperative risk.

ASA-PS Classification:

Class Definition Examples, including, but not limited to:
I A normal healthy patient Healthy, non-smoking, no or minimal alcohol use
II A patient with mild systemic disease Current smoker, well-controlled DM and HTN
III A patient with severe systemic disease Poorly controlled DM or HTN, history (>3 months) of MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD or stents.
IV A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life Recent (< 3 months) MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents
V A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation Ruptured abdominal, thoracic aneurysm, massive trauma, intracranial bleed with mass effect
VI A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be continued on the day of surgery?
questions.solution:
It is recommended to discontinue NSAIDs (Diclofenac), Angiotensin receptor blockers (Losartan) and oral hypoglycemic agents (Metformin) on the day of surgery.

Related Pearl: Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery

Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery:

Drug Duration before discontinuation

Topical medications

 Discontinue on the day of surgery

Diuretics (except thiazides) 

Discontinue on the day of surgery

Oral hypoglycemic agents (except SGLT-2 inhibitors)

Discontinue on the day of surgery

SGLT-2 inhibitors

Discontinue 24 hours before elective surgery and 72 hours before intermediate to high risk surgery

Sildenafil 

Discontinue 24 hours before the day of surgery

NSAIDs 

 Discontinue 48 hours before the day of surgery

Warfarin 

Discontinue 4 days before surgery (except for patients having cataract surgery without a bulbar block)

Short-acting Insulins 

 Discontinued (except when given by a continuous pump)

Thienopyridines (e.g., clopidogrel, ticlopidine) 

 Discontinued (Except in cataract surgery, patients with metallic/drug-eluting stents)

Aspirin 

 Discontinued 3 days before the surgery (except in patients with prior PCI, coronary artery disease and stroke)

MAO Inhibitors

 Discontinued 2 weeks prior 

Related Pearl: Drugs that can be continued on the day of surgery

  1. Antihypertensive medications (Exceptions are ACE Inhibitors and ARB) 
  2. Cardiac medications (e.g., β-blockers, digoxin)
  3. Antidepressants, anxiolytics, and other psychiatric medications
  4. Thyroid medications
  5. Eye drops
  6. Heartburn or reflux medications
  7. Narcotic medications
  8. Anticonvulsants
  9. Asthma medications
  10. Steroids (oral and inhaled)
  11. Statins
  12. Levodopa
  13. Mono Amine Oxidase inhibitors are continued when:(1) Anesthesiologist is comfortable with use of MAO-safe procedures (2) Possibility of exacerbation or precipitation of depressive syndrome.

questions.text: The maximum oxygen delivered by a nasal cannula is?
questions.solution:
The maximum oxygen delivered by a nasal cannula is 40%.

The nasal cannula is a low flow variable performance oxygen delivery system that can provide a maximum inspired oxygen concentration of 40% at flow rates greater than 10 L/ min for short periods. It is usually limited to a flow of 5-6 L/min to reduce the discomfort resulting from inadequate humidification and high flow into the nasal cavity. It may also cause drying and crusting of the nasal mucosa.

Oxygen delivery devices can be broadly divided into low flow oxygen devices (eg: nasal cannula, simple face mask, non-rebreathing mask) and high flow oxygen devices (eg: venturi mask).

Oxygen delivery devices Flow rate (liter/min)  Approximate FiO2
Nasal cannula  1-6  0.24-0.44 
Simple face mask  6-10 0.40-0.60
Non-rebreathing mask 10-15 0.90-1.00 
Venturi mask  2-15  0.24-0.60

questions.text: Traction on which of the following elicits the oculocardiac reflex:
questions.solution:
Traction on  medial rectus elicits the oculocardiac reflex.

Oculocardiac Reflex:

  • It is a trigemino vagal reflex.
  • Results from traction on the medial rectus muscle, orbital periosteum, etc. It could also result from trauma to the eye, administering a retrobulbar block or by even compression of the globe.
  • More common in pediatric patients undergoing squint surgery.
  • The reflex arc involves the afferents passing from the orbital contents to ciliary ganglion to the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve to the sensory nucleus of the trigeminal near the fourth ventricle. The efferent passes via the vagus which is parasympathetic to the heart.
  • The reflex results in bradycardia, atrioventricular block, ventricular ectopy or sometimes asystole.
  • This can be prevented by pre-treatment with atropine or glycopyrrolate.

questions.text: In which of the following patients would you prefer to use an LMA for securing the airway?

choices.text: A term G2P1L1 woman previously diagnosed with pre-eclampsia planned for elective Cesarean section
A 30-year-old patient to be taken up for repair of hiatus hernia
A middle-aged man with a history of diabetes diagnosed with pharyngeal abscess
A 40-year-old woman planned for laparoscopic cholecystectomy, having Mallampatti class III airway

questions.solution:
Laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is indicated in cases with difficult airway where endotracheal intubation is not possible or not available. It can be used as an alternative to an endotracheal tube for ventilating and oxygenating the patient. 

LMA is relatively contraindicated in conditions that are associated with increased risk of aspiration (e.g.: Hiatal hernia, pregnancy, inadequate NPO). LMA may protect the larynx from pharyngeal secretions but not from gastric secretions. The presence of a pharyngeal pathology such as an abscess or tumor, or a pharyngeal obstruction is also a relative contraindication of LMA insertion.

The normal anatomic position of the LMA.

The proximal portion of the LMA rests upon the epiglottis, whereas the distal end or, the tip extends into the pharynx at the upper end of the esophagus. The opening on the laryngeal mask overlies the laryngeal inlet.

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of Laryngeal mask airway (LMA)

Indication:

  • Difficult airway management during cardiopulmonary resuscitation.
  • In emergency where intubation & mask ventilation is not possible. 
  • For minor surgeries, where Anesthetist wants to avoid intubation. 
  • As a conduit for bronchoscopes, small size tubes, gum elastic bougies.

Contraindications:

  • Oropharyngeal abscess or mass
  • Poor mouth opening 
  • Conditions with high risk of aspiration:
    • Hiatus hernia
    • Pregnancy
    • Full stomach patients who are vulnerable to go in bronchospasm
    • Low pulmonary compliance (eg. Obesity)
    • Peak inspiratory pressure > 30 cm of H2O.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient on regular low dose aspirin requires a CABG procedure. What would be your advice regarding aspirin before the procedure?

choices.text: Stop aspirin and replace with heparin
Stop aspirin and give a platelet transfusion
Cancel the surgery as he cannot be operated on

questions.solution:
Aspirin should be continued in patients requiring CABG procedure. 

Discontinuation of aspirin in patients requiring CABG procedure is associated with increased in-hospital mortality. Hence aspirin is continued before the procedure.

The approach for most surgical patients is to discontinue aspirin temporarily for 3 days before surgery to mitigate potential intraoperative bleeding. However, the drug should be continued to prevent cardiovascular thrombotic events in the following:     

  1. Patients with a prior PCI (Percutaneous coronary intervention)
  2. Patients with coronary artery disease 
  3. Patient with stroke in the past 9 months.

 Note: The use of heparin may paradoxically increase platelet aggregation and is not recommended.

questions.text: What is the range of value of Bispectral index (BIS) for a patient who is under general anesthesia?
questions.solution:
The Bispectral index value range of 40-60 is seen in a patient under general anesthesia. 

The bispectral index (BIS) is an empirically derived scale that helps to monitor the depth of anesthesia and prevent intraoperative awareness. It processes the EEG and provides an index value between 0 to 100 that indicates the patient’s level of consciousness.

Bispectral index value range: 

  • 100 - Awake and response to normal voice present
  • 80 - Light/moderate sedation (May respond to loud commands or mild prodding/shaking)
  • 60 - General anesthesia (Low probability of explicit recall, Unresponsive to verbal stimulus)
  • 40 - Deep hypnotic state
  • 20 - Burst suppression
  • 0 - Flatline EEG

questions.text: Acronym AMBU stands for:
questions.solution:
AMBU stands for Artificial Manual Breathing Unit.

It is commonly used to provide positive pressure ventilation to patients who are not breathing or not breathing adequately.

It consists of

  • Self-inflating bag made up of rubber or silicone
  • Ruben non-breathing type of valve and mask

Maximum volume of bag is 1200 ml

questions.text: A 25-year-old is admitted to the ER after being involved in a road traffic accident. Which type of IV cannula would achieve the maximum flow rate to provide fluid resuscitation?
questions.solution:
The orange cannula (14 Gauge) has the maximum flow rate of 270 mL/min.

Tip:

A simple mnemonic to remember these in descending order of their numbering is nature. The mantle zone of the earth is orange, the land is grey, the grass is green, the butterfly on the grass is pink, the sky is blue, and the sun is yellow.

questions.text: A patient who was on ventilator and being ventilated for past few days suddenly pulls out of the endotracheal tube. What is the next step of management?

choices.text: Watch for spontaneous breaths and reintubate if needed

questions.solution: About half of self-extubated patients may not require re-intubation. Pre-extubation FiO2, PaO2/FiO2, and ventilator mode, as well as gender, may be useful in determining the likelihood that a self-extubated patient will require re-intubation and also watch for spontaneous breathing.

questions.text: A patient posted for surgery is taken inside the OT. You observe the following capnograph as the anesthetist starts the procedure. When is this pattern observed?
questions.solution:
The pattern is observed when the anesthetist commences the tracheal intubation of the patient. Tracheal intubation resembles a normal capnogram during controlled mechanical ventilation. 

A capnograph is a simple device that records and shows the concentration of carbon dioxide as a function of time. It describes both the inspiratory and expiratory phases. Phase 0 refers to the inspiratory segment while there are usually three phases during expiration. They are:

  • Phase I is the end of inspiration and the beginning of expiration. It correlates to the expired dead space gas from the central conducting airways or from any equipment distal to the site of sampling. In this phase, the partial pressure of carbon dioxide is zero and thus there is no detectable CO2.
  • Phase II is characterized by a sharp rise in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO2). This is due to the exchange of gases between the conducting airway and alveoli. 
  • Phase III has a plateau component (no rise in PCO2) which depicts the partial pressure of carbon dioxide in the alveoli. It is flat throughout expiration in a homogeneously ventilated lung. 

 The below image shows normal capnography.

Other options:

Option A: In esophageal intubation, the capnograph remains flat or shows small abnormal waveforms which get diminished in height in the following 2 or 3 cycles till they are lost. It can be seen when the endotracheal tube is incorrectly placed. It is shown below.

 

Option B: In rebreathing, the fraction of inspired CO2 is above zero while the shape of the capnograph is preserved with one exception. EtCO2 rises as a consequence. 

Option D: Malignant hyperthermia is characterized by hypoventilation. In this, there is a rise in ETCO2 while the shape is otherwise preserved.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: A 47-year-old female patient was brought to the casualty in an unconscious state after having suddenly collapsed. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation was started as there was no pulse and the following rhythm was noted on the monitor. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario patient has an organized, apparently normal ECG without a palpable pulse, that is, the patient has pulseless electrical activity (PEA). Among the given options, the next step is to give 1 mg of epinephrine.

The immediate treatment for pulseless electrical activity is to give chest compressions and 1 mg epinephrine at the earliest. Following that, definitive treatment for the cause of PEA should be initiated.

It is essential to rule out the reversible causes of cardiac arrest. They include:

5 H’s:

  • Hypovolemia
  • Hypoxia
  • Hydrogen ion (acidosis)
  • Hypokalemia or hyperkalemia
  • Hypothermia

5 T’s:

  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Tamponade (cardiac)
  • Toxins
  • Thrombosis (pulmonary)
  • Thrombosis (coronary)

Other options : 

Option A: Defibrillation is done for treating shockable rhythms. An electric current is passed for a short interval to bring back sinus rhythm. 

Option B: Amiodarone 300 mg IV bolus is used in the treatment of shockable rhythms. After defibrillation CPR is continued for 2 min and then Epinephrine/ Amiodarone is administered alternatively and CPR is continued till sinus rhythm is established. 

Option D: 0.5 mg atropine is the first-line drug for acute symptomatic bradycardia.

questions.text: During laryngoscopy and endotracheal intubation which of the following maneuver is not performed:

choices.text: Extension of the head at atlanto-occipital joint
During laryngoscopy with miller’s blade, the epiglottis is lifted up by the tip
The laryngoscope is lifted upward levering over the upper incisor

questions.solution:
The laryngoscope is lifted upward levering over the upper incisor.

  • Direct laryngoscopy is performed in sniffing position - head elevation 5-10 cm above the surgical table, flexion of the cervical spine and extension at the atlantooccipital joint.
  • During laryngoscopy with miller’s blade, the epiglottis is lifted up by the tip.
  • While performing laryngoscopy, the scope is lifted upwards and never levered over the upper incisors.

questions.text: What is the ideal size of the carbon dioxide absorbent granules?
questions.solution:
The ideal granule size of the carbon dioxide absorbent is between 4 and 8 mesh (1.5-5 mm).

Smaller granule size favors greater area for absorption of carbon dioxide. But, it offers greater airflow resistance (caking).

Converse is true with larger granule size - the absorptive area is less but airflow resistance is minimal (channeling).

So, the ideal size is to be between 4 and 8 mesh as absorptive surface area and resistance to flow are optimized.

questions.text: Which of the following is prevented by the Diameter Index safety system?
questions.solution:
The Diameter Index Safety System (DISS) prevents incorrect pipeline attachment.

DISS is a safety feature in the modern anesthesia workstation. DISS connectors have unique diameters for each type of gas to prevent wrong pipeline attachment to the wrong inlet.

Diameter Index Safety system

Incorrect cylinder attachment(not pipeline) is prevented by Pin Index Safety System.

Contamination of the anesthetic environment by waste gases is prevented by Scavenging system.

Delivery of hypoxic gases is prevented by Oxygen failure safety device (shut-off or proportionating device).

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding baralyme is false?

choices.text: Greater tendency to produce carbon monoxide

questions.solution:
The true statement is baralyme is less efficient than soda-lime.

Baralyme is less efficient than soda-lime as its absorptive capacity is 9-18L of CO2/100 g while of soda lime is 23L of CO2/100 g.

Baralyme with the composition of calcium hydroxide and barium hydroxide (activator) is less caustic than soda lime.

It gives more reliable performance in a dry environment.

As compared to soda lime, baralyme has a greater tendency to produce carbon monoxide.

questions.text: Which is the most common anaphylactic agent during anesthesia?
questions.solution:
The most common anaphylactic agent during anesthesia is antibiotics.

This is followed by neuromuscular blocking agents.

Penicillins and cephalosporins are the most common causes of anaphylaxis among antibiotics.

questions.text: The agent which causes coronary steal phenomenon is?
questions.solution:
Isoflurane causes coronary steal phenomenon.

In coronary artery stenosis patients, Isoflurane causes coronary artery vasodilation in non-ischemic areas, thereby diverting the blood away from ischaemic zones, called as coronary steal phenomenon.

It also reduces blood supply to the ischaemic zones.

Isoflurane dilates coronary arteries, but not nearly as potently as nitroglycerin or adenosine.

questions.text: When a patient is being operated on, which of the following can lead to a decrease in end-tidal CO2 (ETCO2)?
questions.solution:
Fall in ETCO2 (end-tidal carbon dioxide) is seen in cardiac arrest due to decreased blood flow to the lungs.

Increased ETCO2 is seen in thyrotoxicosis, fever (increased CO2 production) and high spinal anesthesia (alveolar hypoventilation).

Factors affecting ETCO2

Increased ETCO2 Decreased ETCO2

Metabolism

  • Hyperthermia
  • Fever
  • Thyrotoxicosis
  • Pain
  • Shivering

Metabolism

  • Hypothermia
  • Metabolic acidosis

Respiratory

  • Hypoventilation
  • Respiratory depression
  • COPD
  • Partial airway obstruction
  • Rebreathing

Respiratory

  • Hyperventilation
  • Total airway obstruction
  • Extubation

Circulatory

  • Increased cardiac output (ROSC after cardiac arrest)
  • Hypertension

Circulatory

  • Hypotension
  • Cardiac arrest
  • Pulmonary emboli

Apparatus malfunction

  • Exhausted CO2 absorber
  • Inadequate fresh gas flow
  • Ventilatory malfunction

Apparatus malfunction

  • Circuit disconnection
  • Leak in sampling
  • Ventilatory malfunction

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the American Society of Anaesthesiologists - Physical Status (ASA-PS) classification?

choices.text: It is used to assess difficulty in intubation
Brain dead patients come under ASA class V
A patient with anaemia without symptoms comes under ASA class III
ASA-PS grading strongly correlates to the peri-operative risk

questions.solution:
ASA-PS classification describes a patient’s preoperative medical status and strongly correlates with the perioperative risk. 

The ASA classification system alone does not predict the perioperative risks, but when used with other factors like the type of surgery, frailty and level of deconditioning of the patient, it can be helpful in predicting perioperative risks.

Option A:  ASA-PS is used to quantify the risk for patients who require anaesthesia, not assess intubation difficulty.

Option B:  Brain dead patients are classified as ASA-PS class Vl.

Option C:  A patient with anaemia without functional limitation (no symptoms) is classified as ASA-PS class ll.

Related Pearl: American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status Classification of Patients

American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status (ASA-PS) classification is used to define relative risk before conscious sedation and surgical anaesthesia and strongly correlates to perioperative risk.

ASA-PS Classification:

Class Definition Examples, including, but not limited to:
I A normal healthy patient Healthy, non-smoking, no or minimal alcohol use
II A patient with mild systemic disease Current smoker, well-controlled DM and HTN
III A patient with severe systemic disease Poorly controlled DM or HTN, history (>3 months) of MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD or stents.
IV A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life Recent (< 3 months) MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents
V A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation Ruptured abdominal, thoracic aneurysm, massive trauma, intracranial bleed with mass effect
VI A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes

questions.text: What is the maximum pressure allowed in an anesthesia reservoir bag?
questions.solution:
The maximum pressure allowed in an anesthesia reservoir bag is 60 cm H20. 

The reservoir bag serves as a reservoir for inhaled excess fresh gas and helps to generate positive pressure ventilation.

It is most commonly placed between the expiratory unidirectional valve and the CO2 absorber.

The minimum allowed pressure is 30 cm H2O.

Anesthesia workstation

questions.text: Identify the given breathing system.
questions.solution:
The given breathing system is the Bain circuit. It is also a type of Mapleson D circuit.

It is a coaxial type of circuit. The identifying feature is the narrow inner tube for the flow of fresh gas. That is, inner tubing is inspiratory and outer tubing is expiratory.

Bain circuit is used for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation.

 

Note: Lack's circuit is a coaxial modification of Mapleson A. Here, inner tubing is expiratory and outer tubing is inspiratory.

Related Pearl: Mapleson Classification

Mapleson circuit   Other name  Fresh gas flow rate
Spontaneous ventilation  Controlled ventilation
A Magills 1 minute ventilation (MV) i.e. 80 ml/kg/min Very high and difficult to predict
B - 2-3× (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
C Water’s to and fro 2-3 × (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
D Bain circuit 2-3 × (MV) 1-2 × (MV)
E Ayre’s t-piece 2-3 × (MV) 3 × (MV)
F Jackson rees modification 2-3 × (MV) 2 × (MV)

 

Note:

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in spontaneous ventilation is  A > DFE > CB (A Dog Can Bite - Usually a spontaneous event)

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation is DFE > BC > A (Dead Babies can't assist - controlled)

questions.text: Which of the following is least metabolized?
questions.solution:
Only 0.02% of desflurane undergoes metabolism.


Metabolism of fluranes:

Methoxyflurane 70% metabolized and desflurane <0.02% is metabolised.

Anaesthetic agent  Metabolism 
Methoxyflurane  70% 
Halothane  25% 
Enflurane  2.5% 
Sevoflurane  5% 
Isoflurane  0.2% 
Desflurane  0.02%

questions.text: In what position would you place a patient prior to direct laryngoscopy?
questions.solution:
Prior to direct laryngoscopy and intubation, the patient is placed in the sniffing position, which consists of flexion at the lower cervical spine with extension at the atlanto-occipital joint.

This is to ensure a line of sight from the mouth to the larynx so that intubation can be performed with ease. 

Cervical flexion of 35 degrees is provided by elevating the patient's head by 7-9 cm (folded sheet under the head). This aligns the pharyngeal and laryngeal axes. 

Atlanto-occipital extension is provided by the head tilt. This brings into alignment the visual axis of the mouth with that of pharyngeal and laryngeal axes.

Adequacy of head elevation can be estimated by checking the horizontal alignment between external auditory meatus and sternal notch.

questions.text: In Damage Control resuscitation (DCR), the ratio of RBCs, fresh frozen plasma and platelets is of the order:
questions.solution:
• In DCR, the ratio of RBC: FFP: Platelets is 1:1:1.
  • Administering blood products in the appropriate ratios in order to facilitate resuscitation from trauma and avert trauma induced coagulopathy is termed Damage Control Resuscitation (DCR).
  • Red blood cell component will improve oxygen delivery to ischemic tissues.
  • Fresh frozen plasma improves clotting by providing clotting factors V and VIII and fibrinogen.
  • Platelet transfusion is required if the platelet count is below 50,000 / high power field, significant blood loss or prolonged resuscitation.
  • Though the current hemostatic resuscitation ratio is 1:1:1, use of less fresh frozen plasma and more of antifibrinolytics is advocated by some experts.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about Mallampati classification except _______

choices.text: It is used to predict difficult tracheal intubation
Higher scores on the Mallampati classification indicate poor visibility of the oropharyngeal structures
Only hard palate is visualised in Class III
Tonsillar pillars are visualised in Class I

questions.solution:
• Only the hard palate is visualized in Class IV of Mallampati classification.

Mallampati classification is used to predict difficult tracheal intubation based on the size of the base of the tongue.

  • The patient is seated upright with the head neutral, and mouth open, the tongue protruded, and no phonation (Patient should NOT say 'aah').
  • A Mallampati classification of I to IV is assigned, based on the visibility of the faucial pillars, uvula, and soft palate.
  • Higher scores on the Mallampati classification indicate poor visibility of the oropharyngeal structures attributable to a large tongue relative to the size of the oropharyngeal space, and, subsequently, leading to more difficult intubation.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: You are an anaesthesia resident posted in the pediatrics OT. A spontaneously breathing 6 year old child is set to undergo a minor elective procedure. Which of the following circuits would be the best choice for ventilating this patient?
questions.solution:
Jackson Rees modification of Ayre's T piece is the circuit of choice for ventilating a spontaneously breathing child during anesthesia.

Jackson Rees modification of Ayre's T piece is classified as a Mapleson's F system, although it was not included in the original description by Prof Mapleson.

It is used in children <6 years or <20 kgs.

Mapleson Circuit Comments
Type A (Magill's circuit)

Circuit of choice for spontaneous ventilation
Type B

Obsolete

Type C (Water's to and fro)

Obsolete
Type D (Bain's circuit)

Circuit of choice for controlled ventilation. Most commonly used circuit.
Type E (Ayre's T piece)

Circuit of 2nd choice in children
Type F (Jackson Rees Modification) Circuit of choice in children (<20 kg)

Jackson Rees modification of Ayre's T piece. 

FGI - Fresh gas inlet; RB - Reservoir bag; P - Patient

questions.text: Which among the following IV anaesthetics does not cause myocardial depression?
questions.solution:
Etomidate, a short-acting I.V. anesthetic agent doesn’t cause myocardial depression.

Etomidate is the most cardiac stable intravenous agent due to its lack of effect on the sympathetic nervous system and on the function of the baroreceptor. Hence, etomidate is the I.V. agent of choice in patients with coronary artery disease, cardiomyopathy, and cerebral vascular disease.

Side effects of Etomidate:

  • The highest incidence of nausea and vomiting among inducing agents
  • Superficial thrombophlebitis and pain on injection
  • Adrenocortical suppression

Note: Although Ketamine has an indirect sympathetic stimulatory effect, it possesses a direct negative inotropic effect on the myocardium. Hence, ketamine has to be used cautiously in critically ill patients with shock, as they are prone to have a depletion of endogenous catecholamines. Ketamine infusion in such patients can unmask its direct negative inotropic effects and further decrease the blood pressure and cardiac output.

Hence, for this MCQ, Etomidate is the best answer.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true concerning Compound A?

choices.text: Seen predominantly with high flow techniques

questions.solution:
The true statement concerning Compound A is that its formation is less common with Amsorb absorbent.

Compound A is fluoro-methyl-2,2-difluoro-1-(trifluoromethyl) vinyl ether which is the degradation product of Sevoflurane, not desflurane.

The strong bases like NaOH and KOH present in absorbents (soda lime) lead to its formation. Lack of strong alkali in Amsorb makes its formation less common.

Compound A is nephrotoxic, not neurotoxic.

It is seen predominantly with low flow anesthesia techniques and high absorbent temperatures.

questions.text: You notice this  specialized vaporizer being used in the OT. Which of the following gases would you expect it to contain?
questions.solution:
The image shows a specialized vapouriser Tec 6. Because of high vapor pressure (669 mmHg at 20°C) and low boiling point (22.8°C ~ room temperature), Desflurane requires this specialized vaporizer for its delivery.

Anesthetic gas with the highest vapor pressure is Desflurane. 

Other salient features of Desflurane:

  • High saturated vapor pressure which is 3-4 times the other agents
  • Low boiling point 
  • Low blood-gas solubility (0.42) resulting in rapid uptake and recovery
  • High MAC value of 6, indicating low potency
  • Requires specialized vapouriser such as Tec 6
  • Color coding of Desflurane - Blue
  • Undergoes minimal metabolism
  • Degraded into CO by the desiccated CO2 absorbent

questions.text: A child operated for bladder extrophy for renal failure. Anesthesia of choice is:
questions.solution:
Always in renal or hepatic failure, the muscle relaxant of choice is atracurium.

Dose: 0.5 mg/Kg. Duration of action: 15-20 min. t1/2: 20 min.

It gets metabolized by Hoffman degradation in plasma (95%), ester hydrolysis (5%) and produces laudanosine which crosses BBB and may produce convulsions(Doubtful clinical significance).

Atracurium releases histamine. Allergic reactions to Atracurium range from a pruritic rash to angioneurotic edema.

It is a relaxant of choice in:

  • Renal failure
  • Hepatic failure
  • Patients with atypical pseudocholinesterase
  • Myasthenia gravis (1/10th of a normal dose)
  • Small children

questions.text: In a road traffic accident victim with a GCS scale of 8/15, rapid-sequence intubation is planned. Which of the following is not done in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Manual ventilation before intubation is not done in rapid-sequence induction (RSI).

RSI is done during emergency surgery, with the objective of securing the airway rapidly and preventing aspiration.

Steps of RSI are shown in the image below:

Steps not done in RSI:

  • Manual ventilation before intubation: Avoided as this inflates the stomach and causes regurgitation
  • Premedications: Not given as surgery is done immediately under emergency

RSI is avoided in patients with raised intracranial pressure as it worsens the condition.

questions.text: Dead space is increased in all except:
questions.solution:
Dead space is increased in all except artificial airway. Dead space is the volume of a breath that does not participate in gas exchange. It is ventilation without perfusion.

  • Total dead space (Physiological dead space) = Anatomical dead space+ alveolar dead space.
  • Anatomical dead space is the area in the tracheobronchial tree where the gaseous exchange between the lung and capillaries doesn’t take place. It includes nasal cavity, larynx, trachea, bronchi, end of the terminal bronchiole.
  • Alveolar dead space is the volume of gas within unperfused alveoli (and thus not participating in gas exchange either)

 

 

Factors affecting dead space:

  • Posture:

         Upright - Increase

         Supine - Decrease

  • Position of Airway:

         Neck Extension - Increase

         Neck Flexion - Decrease

  • Others:

        Age - Increase

        Artificial airway - Decrease

        Positive pressure ventilation - Increase

        Drug anti-cholinergic - Increase

  • Pulmonary perfusion:

        Pulmonary embolism - Increase

        Hypotension - Increase

  • Pulmonary vascular disease:

        Emphysema - Increase

questions.text: Fire breaks out during laser vocal cord surgery. What is not to be done?

choices.text: Treatment with bronchial lavage and steroids

questions.solution:
100% oxygen after discontinuing anesthetic gas should not be done.

  • Oxygen should be turned off, the tube should be removed and the patient should be ventilated with a face mask.
  • 100 percent oxygen may be restarted once the fire is extinguished and the patient is reintubated.

AIRWAY FIRE PROTOCOL:

  • Stop the procedure and extinguish the fire with a saline wash.
  • Stop ventilation and remove the endotracheal tube
  • Turn off the oxygen and disconnect the circuit from the machine.
  • Assess airway damage with bronchoscopy, serial chest x-ray and ABGs
  • Consider bronchial lavage and steroids
  • Ventilate with face mask and reintubate

questions.text: In a flowmeter sequence, which of the following cylinders is placed downstream?
questions.solution:
The oxygen flowmeter is located downstream of the other flowmeters. This is to avoid the generation of a hypoxic mixture in the event of any air leak.

In the first two images, A and B, the nitrous oxide flowmeter is located downstream and there is a leak in the airflow tube. Through this leak, most of the oxygen passes out and mainly nitrous oxide is provided at the outlet leading to the production of a hypoxic mixture.

But in the other two images, C and D, the oxygen flowmeter is located downstream. Through the leak in the airflow tube, some of the nitrous oxide passes out and the remaining passes out through the outlet with the oxygen. Thus the production of a hypoxic mixture is less likely if oxygen flowmeter is placed downstream.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient has been on tablet fluoxetine for depression for the past 3 months and is now scheduled to undergo elective surgery. What would you advise him?

choices.text: Withhold  Fluoxetine for 3 weeks prior to surgery
Withhold fluoxetine  for 3 days prior to surgery
Withhold fluoxetine and replace with monoamine oxidase inhibitors

questions.solution:
Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), an antidepressant, and is to be continued on the day of surgery to avoid exacerbation of symptoms.

Abrupt withdrawal of short-acting SSRIs should be avoided, as it can cause a discontinuation syndrome including dizziness, chills, muscle aches, and anxiety.

Related Pearl: Drugs that can be continued on the day of surgery

  1. Antihypertensive medications (Exceptions are ACE Inhibitors and ARB) 
  2. Cardiac medications (e.g., β-blockers, digoxin)
  3. Antidepressants, anxiolytics, and other psychiatric medications
  4. Thyroid medications
  5. Eye drops
  6. Heartburn or reflux medications
  7. Narcotic medications
  8. Anticonvulsants
  9. Asthma medications
  10. Steroids (oral and inhaled)
  11. Statins
  12. Levodopa
  13. Mono Amine Oxidase inhibitors are continued when:(1) Anesthesiologist is comfortable with use of MAO-safe procedures (2) Possibility of exacerbation or precipitation of depressive syndrome.

questions.text: The following capnographic tracing is seen in?
questions.solution:
The image shows a "pigtail" capnogram which occurs due to the sudden spike of expired CO2  caused by sudden airway closure.

It is typically seen in poor lung compliance, pregnant women and obese patients.

It occurs when a poorly compliant lung secondary to pregnancy squeezes the last few mL of CO2 rich gas from the alveoli.

Subsequently, the collapse of the lung parenchyma occludes the small bronchi and puts an end to the escape of gas.

 

Endobronchial intubation:

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: What is the maximum cuff pressure that you can use to inflate the cuff of an endotracheal tube?
questions.solution:
Cuff pressure should not exceed 25 cm of H2O since excess cuff pressure can lead to tracheal mucosal injury and recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy.

Cuff should be inflated to the minimum volume at which no air leak is seen.

If nitrous oxide is used in general anesthesia, then cuff pressure should be monitored periodically as nitrous oxide can diffuse into the cuff causing the cuff pressure to rise.

questions.text: A 42-year-old epileptic patient is posted for general anesthesia. Which of the following is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ketamine should be avoided in patients with a history of seizures as it further increases ICP and also causes delirium and hallucinations.

Ketamine:

  • Ketamine should be avoided in patients with a history of seizures.
  • Increases brain oxygen consumption and metabolic rate, intracranial tension is highly raised.
  • Hallucination is the most common side effect of ketamine.
  • Emergence reaction (vivid dreaming, illusion etc)

Thiopentone:

  • Agent of choice for cerebral protection
  • Anticonvulsant action due to the phenyl group

Propofol:

  • Decreases ICP
  • Neuroprotective

Midazolam:

  •   Used in treating seizures
