questions.text: Pin index given for oxygen gas under pin index system is _________
questions.solution:
Pin index system for oxygen gas is 2, 5.

Pin index safety system(PISS) is a safety measure to prevent incorrect cylinder attachment.

Related Pearl: Pin index safety system (PISS):

Note:

  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with more than 7% CO2: 1,6
  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with less than 7% CO2: 2,6

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was brought to the casualty with complaints of palpitations and dizziness. His pulse rate was 130/min and blood pressure 120/70 mm Hg. His ECG is shown below. What is the line of management?
questions.solution:
The patient has monomorphic ventricular tachycardia but it hasn’t caused hemodynamic deterioration.  So pharmacological treatment is initiated with procainamide.

Procainamide is a class Ia antiarrhythmic drug. The loading dose for procainamide is 20 to 50 mg/min which is given until the arrhythmia is suppressed, hypotension develops, the QRS prolongs by 50% or a total dose of 17 mg/kg is administered. The maintenance dose is 1 to 4 mg/min.

If the patient is unstable with any one of the following:

  • Pulseless
  • Hypotension
  • Acutely altered mental status
  • Signs of shock
  • Ischemic chest discomfort
  • Acute heart failure

   Then immediate synchronized cardioversion should be given

   Monophasic – 360 J

   Biphasic - 120 J

It is essential to rule out the reversible causes of ventricular tachycardia like Hypoxemia, hypercapnia, hypokalemia or hypomagnesemia (or both), digitalis toxicity and acid-base disturbances.

questions.text: All are components of Basic Life Support (BLS), except:
questions.solution:
Needle cricothyrotomy is not a component of BLS. It is a component of Advanced Life Support (ALS).

Components of BLS:

  • Airway - Manual
  • Breathing - Bag and Mask
  • Circulation - Cardiac massage
  • Defibrillation - Automated External Defibrillator/Public access Defibrillator

Related Pearl: Neurocutaneous syndomes

Von Hippel Lindau Syndrome:

  • Autosomal dominant
  • Gene defect: VHL gene, tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 3
  • Conditions associated with it include:
    • Renal cell carcinoma
    • Hemangioblastomas
    • Pheochromocytomas
    • Angiomatosis
    • Cysts in the pancreas, liver, and kidneys

Neurofibromatosis type 1: 

  • Also known as Von Recklinghausen Disease
  • Autosomal dominant
  • Gene defect: NF1 gene on chromosome 17, codes for the Neurofibromin protein
  • Features of NF 1:  “CAFE SPOTS”
    • Café-au-lait spots (multiple, >6, >5 mm in children or >15 mm in adults)
    • Axillary or inguinal freckling
    • Family history (autosomal dominant inheritance)
    • Eye findings (Lisch nodules on the iris)
    • Skin neurofibromas (benign tumors)
    • Plexiform neurofibromas (larger, deeper tumors)
    • Optic pathway gliomas (tumors of the optic nerve)
    • Tibial dysplasia (bone abnormalities, e.g., bowing of the tibia)
    • Skeletal abnormalities (e.g., scoliosis)

Neurofibromatosis type 2:

  • Autosomal dominant
  • Gene defect: NF2 gene on chromosome 22 that codes for the Merlin protein
  • Features: "MISME"
    • Multiple schwannomas (bilateral vestibular schwannomas are hallmark)
    • Intracranial meningiomas
    • Spinal tumors (ependymomas, schwannomas)
    • Meningiomas (intracranial or spinal)
    • Ependymomas (spinal cord tumors)

Tuberous sclerosis: 

  • Autosomal dominant
  • Mutation in the TSC 1 gene on chromosome 9 and TSC 2 on chromosome 16
  • Features: “HAMARTOMAS”
    • Hamartomas in skin and CNS
    • Ash-leaf spots (Hypopigmented macules)
    • Mitral regurgitation
    • Angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum)
    • Rhabdomyomas of the heart
    • Tuberous sclerosis
    • Autosomal dOMinant
    • Angiomyolipomas
    • Seizures and shagreen patches
    • Also associated with intellectual disability

Sturge Weber Syndrome

  • Also known as encephalotrigeminal angiomatosis
  • Somatic mosaicism due to mutation in GNAQ gene
  • Features: “STURGE - I”
    • Portwine Stain (Nevus flammeus)
    • Tram track calcifications (leptomeningeal angioma)
    • Unilateral weakness
    • Retinal detachment and atrophy
    • Glaucoma
    • Epilepsy
    • Intellectual disability

questions.text: During an elective operation, you observe the following breathing circuit is used to provide anaesthesia. Which of the following is not true regarding this system?
questions.solution:
The circle system is not associated with increased air pollution.

The incidence of air pollution: Open>Mapleson>Circle system.

The ability to scavenge exhaled gases is also maximum with a closed system. Scavenging is the process of removal of waste anesthetic gases from both the anesthesia machine and the anesthetizing location (operation theatre). Thus minimizing operating room pollution.


Components of the circle system: 

  • CO2 absorber
  • fresh gas inlet
  • uni-directional valves (inspiratory and expiratory)
  • Breathing tubes (inspiratory and expiratory)
  • Y-connector
  • APL valve
  • Reservoir bag.

The circle system allows for a uni-directional flow of anesthetic gases.

Carbon dioxide absorber (eg soda-lime) allows rebreathing of anesthetic gases after the removal of exhaled carbon dioxide. This conserves anesthetic gases and thus reduces air pollution.

How green is my operation theatre? 

Almost all anesthetic gases (volatile agents and nitrous oxide) are aggressive greenhouse gases. With <5% being metabolized by the body, the vast majority of the anesthetic is routinely vented to the atmosphere from the operating room. The global warming potential of a halogenated anesthetic is up to 2,000 times greater than that of CO2.

questions.text: Regarding endotracheal intubation in infants, which is true:

choices.text: Miller blade is used since it is straight
Macintosh blade is used since it provides greater room for passage
Miller blade is advantageous since it causes less damage to teeth
The size of the intubation tube used is 4.5 for full term infants

questions.solution:
• There are two types of laryngoscopic blades available for intubation:
    • Curved blade
    • Straight blade
  • Miller is the most commonly used straight blade and is used neonates, infants and young children, patients with short thyromental distance and long floppy epiglottis.
  • Macintosh is the most commonly used curved blade and is preferred for adults.
  • Advantage of curved blade:
  • Greater room available for the passage for an endotracheal tube
  • Less damage to the teeth
  • Size of an endotracheal tube usually refers to the internal diameter in mm. In infants, it is 3.5 mm
Age Endoscopic - Internal diameter (mm) Length (cm)
Full-term infant 3.5         12
Child 4  + Age/4     12 + Age/2
Adult male 7.5 - 9.0          24
Adult female 7.0–7.5          24

questions.text: A 70 kg athlete was posted for surgery and he was administered succinylcholine due to unavailability of vecuronium. It was administered in intermittent dosing (total 640 mg). During recovery, the patient was not able to respire spontaneously & move limbs. What is the reason for the same?

choices.text: Muscular weakness due to fasciculation produced by succinylcholine
Undiagnosed muscular dystrophy and muscular weakness
Phase II blockade produced by succinyl choline
Pseudocholinesterase deficiency increasing action of succinylcholine

questions.solution:
The best answer to the above case scenario is phase II blockade produced by succinylcholine.

Phase II block is clinically seen with the dose >5 mg/kg.

Mechanism of action of succinylcholine:

  • Phase I block: continuous endplate depolarization and subsequent muscle relaxation.
  • Phase II block: seen with a large single dose, repeated doses, or a continuous infusion which can lead to desensitization of the receptors resulting in a prolonged neuromuscular blockade.

Causes of prolonged apnea include:

  • Atypical/pseudocholinesterase deficiency - can result in apnea even with a normal dose of succinylcholine
  • The altered response of endplate to depolarizing relaxant (myasthenia gravis)
  • Accumulation of succinylcholine leading to phase II blockade

Although options B, C, and D can lead to prolonged apnea, in the above case scenario, the patient has received ~9mg/kg of succinylcholine. Hence the most probable diagnosis is phase II blockade leading to prolonged apnea.

Related Pearl: Side effects of succinyl choline

The following are the side effects of succinyl choline:

  • Cardiovascular effects:
    • Sinus bradycardia
    • Junctional rhythms
    • Ventricular dysrhythmias
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Myalgia
  • Masseter spasm: Succinyl choline can trigger malignant hyperthermia
  • Increased intracranial pressure: Succinylcholine may lead to an activation of the EEG and slight increases in CBF and ICP in some patients.
  • Increased intraocular pressure
  • Increased intragastric pressure

questions.text: A junior resident accidentally administered thiopentone intra-arterial to a patient. Management should involve all of the following except ___________
questions.solution:
The injection needle should not be removed in case of intraarterial thiopentone injection.

Treatment for intraarterial thiopentone injection:

  • If thiopentone is administered intra-arterially stop the injection immediately and further injection of the drug should not be done.
  • Injection needle should not be removed. This is done because saline can be administered via the same needle to dilute the drug.
  • Administer heparin to prevent thrombosis.
  • Brachial plexus block or stellate ganglion block

questions.text: A patient had bilateral pain in buttocks radiating to legs within 24 hours after undergoing surgery under spinal anaesthesia. There is no other neurological abnormality. This is most likely due to which of the following anaesthetic?
questions.solution:
Bilateral pain in buttocks radiating to legs within 24 hours after undergoing surgery under spinal anaesthesia, is suggestive of transient neurological symptoms which is seen in case of Lidocaine and mepivacaine. It is less frequent with bupivacaine.

Transient neurological symptoms:

  • It is commonly associated with spinal lidocaine (not commonly associated with epidural lidocaine)
  • The phenomenon is related to the concentration of lidocaine, the addition of dextrose or epinephrine, or solution osmolarity.
  • Symptoms are usually characterized by bilateral or unilateral pain in the buttocks radiating to the legs or, less commonly, isolated buttock or leg pain. Symptoms occur within 24 hours of the resolution of an otherwise uneventful spinal anesthetic and are not associated with any neurologic deficits or laboratory abnormalities.
  • TNS occurs more commonly in patients who are placed in the lithotomy position for surgery.
  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are the first line of treatment, but pain can be severe and may even require opioids.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common complication following the use of a laryngeal mask airway?
questions.solution:
Sore throat is the most common symptom following the use of a laryngeal mask airway with an incidence of 10-20%.

Injury to the lingual, hypoglossal, and recurrent laryngeal nerves are rare. 

These complications can be minimized by using an adequate sized device and avoiding high cuff pressures.

questions.text: Preoperative fasting recommendation is _________

choices.text: 2 hours for breast milk in infants

questions.solution:
Preoperative fasting recommendation is 2 hours for liquids in adults.

Recommended Preoperative Fasting period:

  • For neonates and infants:
    • 2 hours for clear fluids
    • 4 hours for breast milk
    • 6 hours for solids and infant formula
  • For all above 1 year of age:
    • 2 hours for clear fluids
    • 6 hours for a light meal
    • 8 hours if the meal contains fried, fatty food

Preoperative fasting is intended to reduce the risk of pulmonary aspiration.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman was taken up for Cesarean section. Spinal anesthesia was given and the patient went into hypotension. Which of the following would be the vasopressor of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Phenylephrine is the vasopressor of choice in pregnant patients developing hypotension following neuraxial anesthesia (spinal and epidural).

Phenylephrine is preferred because besides effectively controlling hypotension, it has less placental transfer and lesser chances of fetal acidosis than ephedrine.

The patient should receive an adequate intravenous fluid bolus of crystalloid like Ringer lactate solution (typically 1000–1500 mL) or colloid (typically 250–500 mL) solution at the time of neural blockade to avoid hypotension. On developing hypotension even after adequate fluid management, vasopressors are administered for the further management.

After the administration of the spinal anesthetic injection, the patient is placed supine with left uterine displacement (to prevent aortocaval compression) and supplemental oxygen (40–50%) is given.

Blood pressure should be monitored every 1–2 min until it stabilizes.

Hypotension following epidural anesthesia typically has a slower onset.

Other options:

Option A- Dopamine is not used in pregnant women developing hypotension because it lowers the pO2 levels in umbilical vessels. 

Option B- Vasopressin is reserved for circulatory collapse or patients who do not respond to volume infusion and catecholamines. Hence, it is not preferred here.

Option C- Ephedrine has more placental transfer and there is a higher risk of fetal acidosis.

questions.text: You notice the resident performing Pre-oxygenation before induction,  in a patient with an adequate respiratory drive. He would be performing the preoxygenation for how much time?
questions.solution:
Pre-oxygenation (Denitrogenation) before induction should be given for 3 minutes.

The aim of pre-oxygenation before induction is to improve the oxygen reservoir of the lungs by replacing Nitrogen with 100% oxygen for 3 minutes.

In case of emergency conditions where affording 3 minutes is life-threatening, then, the patient is asked to take 4-5 deep breaths with 100% oxygen as an alternative.

questions.text: What is the most commonly used Mapleson circuit?
questions.solution:
The most commonly used Mapleson circuit system is Mapleson circuit type D.

Mapleson classified the semi-closed anesthetic breathing system according to

  • The position of the expiratory valve
  • The fresh gas flow inlet
  • Position/presence of the reservoir bag

Mapleson's system includes Type A, B, C, D, E, and F.

Mapleson circuit type D is the circuit of choice for controlled ventilation.

Note: The Bain circuit is a coaxial version of the Mapleson D system that incorporates the fresh gas inlet tubing inside the breathing tube. Bain circuit, unlike Mapleson D, can also be used for spontaneous ventilation.

 

Schimmelbusch mask used for open drop method of anesthesia

Closed or Circle system

Professor William Mapleson (1926-2018), best known for his classification of respiratory circuits was an honorable recipient of Sir Ivan Magill Gold medal in 2002. His recent demise at the age of 92 was one of the greatest loss for the anesthesia community.

Related Pearl: Identification of Mapleson's circuits

Mapleson System

 Fresh gas flow inlet APL valve location Reservoir bag Corrugated tubing Example and comments
A Near bag Near patient Present Present

Magill;

Lack (co-axial) 
B Near patient Near patient Present Present Obsolete
C Near patient Near patient Present Absent Obsolete; Still used in emergency resuscitation (AMBU bag)
D Near patient Away from patient Present Present Bain (co-axial)
E Near patient Absent Absent Present Ayre's T piece
F Near patient Absent Present Present Jackson Rees Modification for pediatric patients

questions.text: An 8-year old child is brought to the casualty in respiratory distress. In order to intubate this child, which is the appropriate size of endotracheal tube to be used?
questions.solution:
The appropriate size of the endotracheal tube for a child is chosen by the formula: 4 + age/4.

 

So the correct sized tube for this child would be 6 mm.

  • Size of an endotracheal tube usually refers to the internal diameter in mm. Rarely  the French scale is used where the size corresponds to the external diameter multiplied by 3.
  • For adults, usually a 7-mm is used for women and an 8-mm ETT is used for men.
               Age   Internal Diameter (mm)        Length (cm)
Full-term infant 3.5 12
Child 4  + Age/4 14 + Age/2
Adult Female 7.0–7.5 21 (average)
Male 7.5–9.0 23 (average)
  • Besides age, choice of an endotracheal tube also depends on the presence of airway pathologies and the reason behind placement of the tube.
  • Smaller sized tubes lead to increase airway resistance and increased work of breathing.
  • Larger tubes have higher risk of laryngeal and tracheal trauma and sore throat.

questions.text: During the pre-anaesthetic evaluation of a patient, the oral cavity examined is depicted in the image given below. The image shows which class of the Mallampati score?
questions.solution:
The image of the oral cavity shows the soft palate and the base of the uvula, and is thus graded as Mallampati class III.

Mallampati classification is an important component of airway examination. It is used to assess the visibility of the faucial pillars, uvula, and soft palate in an upright position with the patient's head neutral, mouth open, tongue protruded, and no phonation. 

Higher scores indicate poor visibility of these structures due to the presence of a large tongue. Thus, Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati classes III and IV are considered features of difficult airway.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

questions.text: The following capnographic waveform is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The given capnographic waveform is suggestive of bronchospasm.

Capnography refers to the method of CO2 measurement as a function of time or volume. Bronchospasms may be due to respiratory pathologies like asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), or acute lung injury. Another cause of this waveform is a partially obstructed endotracheal tube or breathing circuit. Capnographic changes in bronchospasm include:

  • Loss of verticality of Phase II
  • The opening of the angle between phases 2 and 3 (α angle)
  • Increased upslope of phase III
  • No plateau before the next inspiration
  • Shark fin appearance - in severe cases

 Normal capnography is shown in the image below:

Other options:

Option A: Malignant hyperthermia would show a progressive rise in the end-tidal CO2 due to the increased metabolic rate.

Option C: Rebreathing will show the failure of CO2 to return to the baseline at the end of the expiration. The inspiratory CO2 remains above 0.

Option D: Accidental extubation or circuit disconnection would show a sudden cessation of CO2.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: You are observing the ET CO2 monitor of the patient in the OT. Your attending asks you what the plateau phase in the waveform represents. What should be your answer?

choices.text: Transition gases between airways and alveoli

questions.solution:
In a capnographic waveform, the plateau phase corresponds to alveolar air.

The normal waveform has four different phases:

Phase I: Inspiratory baseline, represents the CO2-free gas from the airways (anatomical and apparatus dead space).

Phase II: Expiratory upstroke, mixing of dead space gas with alveolar gas.

Phase III: Alveolar plateau, represents CO2-rich gas from the alveoli. The last of the alveolar gas is sampled to measure ETCO2.

Phase 0: Inspiratory downstroke and the beginning of inspiration.

Alpha angle: The transition from phase II to III.
The alpha angle can be used to assess the ventilation/perfusion of the lung. V/Q mismatches will have an alpha angle greater than 90 degrees.

Beta angle: The transition from phase III to 0.
The beta angle can be used to assess rebreathing. If rebreathing occurs, the angle is greater than 90 degrees.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is seen in the emergency department after he had collapsed after a dental extraction in which topical anesthesia was used. The patient is deeply cyanosed despite a good respiratory effort, a clear airway, and bilateral breath sounds. Although he initially responds to vocal commands, his level of consciousness soon deteriorates. Oxygen saturation is 60% with the patient breathing room air. An endotracheal tube is introduced and assisted ventilation started, but this does not improve his cyanosis or level of consciousness. Which of the following topical anesthetics could be responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical history is suggestive of methemoglobinemia, which is common side effect with prilocaine.

  • The possible diagnosis of methemoglobinemia can be made because the patient is cyanosed, the cyanosis is unresponsive to ventilation, there is no prior history of respiratory problems, and the patient had been exposed to a topical anesthetic that is known to cause methemoglobinemia.
  • Hepatic metabolism of prilocaine generates O-toluidine, which oxidizes hemoglobin to methemoglobin.

Treatment:

  • Severe methemoglobinemia is a medical emergency, requiring prompt recognition and appropriate treatment.
  • It can be treated with intravenous administration of methylene blue, whose action depends on the availability of reduced nicotinamide adenine nucleotide phosphate (NADPH) within the red blood cell.
  • Dextrose should be givenas the major source of NADH in the red blood cells is the catabolism of sugar through glycolysis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male was brought to the casualty with multiple stab injuries over the abdomen. He was immediately prepared for emergency surgery and an endotracheal tube was inserted. Following intubation,  capnography was performed and end-tidal CO2 was detected. But his oxygen saturation dropped to 60 and there were no breath sounds audible over the left hemithorax. This is probably because of?
questions.solution:
• Detection of end-tidal CO2 but dropping oxygen saturation and hypoxia with absent breath sounds over the left hemithorax point to endobronchial intubation into the right main bronchus.
  • Endobronchial intubation is first indicated by a sudden rise in peak inspiratory pressure.
  • Capnography and detection of end-tidal CO2 is the surest confirmation for endotracheal intubation but it does not differentiate endotracheal from endobronchial intubation.
  • Signs of endobronchial intubation.
  • Elevated peak inspiratory pressure and other airway pressures
  • Asymmetric chest expansion
  • Unilateral breath sounds
  • Hypoxemia
  • Signs of correct endotracheal intubation:
    • Detection of end tidal CO2 by capnography (SUREST CONFIRMATION)
    • Symmetric chest rise
    • Bilateral breath sounds
    • Absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium
    • Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube
    • Large exhaled tidal volumes
    • Appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation
  • During an esophageal intubation, initial end tidal CO2 may be detected due to swallowed air but later becomes zero and there would be absence of breath sounds bilaterally with presence of breath sounds in the epigastrium.

questions.text: A person is on herbal medications. If he has to undergo any surgery, the most appropriate advice given would be:

choices.text: Stop them 2 days before surgery since they might cause adverse effects
Continue them along with anti-allergic medications
Stop them as early as 2 weeks since they might cause increased operative bleeding

questions.solution:
• Herbal medications should be discontinued at least 2 weeks before surgery due to adverse perioperative events associated with their use.
  • For example, the use of garlic and ginger has been associated with increased operative bleeding when whereas others may increase allergic reactions.
  • They may interfere with the action of the anesthetic drugs used.
  • Besides, the composition of herbal medicines may be unpredictable leading to numerous adverse effects and drug interactions.

questions.text: Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with less than 7% CO2 will have pin index ___________
questions.solution:
Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with less than 7% CO2 will have pin index 2, 6.

Related Pearl: Pin index safety system (PISS):

Note:

  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with more than 7% CO2: 1,6
  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with less than 7% CO2: 2,6

questions.text: In a patient undergoing mitral valve repair, which is the most sensitive indicator of myocardial ischemia?
questions.solution:
Transesophageal echocardiography is the most sensitive indicator of myocardial ischemia.  

New regional wall motion abnormalities (RWMA) and decreased systolic wall thickening on transesophageal echocardiography are more sensitive than ECG.

Ischemia may be indicated clinically by a sudden onset intraoperative arrhythmia or conduction block.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions does this capnographic waveform appear?
questions.solution:
The above capnographic waveform shows an elevated inspiratory baseline, which depicts rebreathing.

Rebreathing of CO2 may occur due to exhausted soda lime or incompetent expiratory valve in closed-circuit breathing systems.

Option A: Malignant hyperthermia shows progressive rise in ETCO2 

Option B: Bronchospasm shows a shark fin appearance

Option D: Accidental extubation shows flat ETCO2 trace

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: In a patient undergoing pulmonary artery catheterisation, which of the following would denote entry into the pulmonary artery?
questions.solution:
Entry into the pulmonary artery is indicated by an increase in diastolic pressure.

Pulmonary artery catheterization involves the use of a Swan-Ganz catheter.

questions.text: Tracheostomy reduces anatomical dead space by:
questions.solution:
Tracheostomy decreases dead space by bypassing the upper airways.

Tracheostomy also decreases the V/Q ratio.

It also reduces airflow resistance.

questions.text: Most common complication of the block shown in the image below is ___________
questions.solution:
The image depicts interscalene block which is performed between the anterior and middle scalene muscles in the interscalene groove at the level of C6. Diaphragmatic paresis is the most common complication seen in interscalene block (seen in 100%). It is due to ipsilateral phrenic nerve blockade.

This can result in dyspnea, hypoxia, and hypercapnea especially if the patient has compromised lung function or pre existing contralateral phrenic nerve paralysis. It can be minimized by performing ultrasound guided blocks, using smaller volumes of local anaesthetic and blocking the brachial plexus at a lower level in the neck.

Other complications of interscalene block are:

  • Horners syndrome – ptosis, myosis, anhydrosis. Due to involvement of the sympathetic nerves to the cervicothoracic ganglion
  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
  • Vagus nerve involvement
  • Pneumothorax
  • Bezold Jarisch reflex
  • Accidental vertebral artery injection (immediate seizure is seen)
  • Accidental spinal or epidural injection

questions.text: Propofol infusion syndrome is associated with all except:
questions.solution:
Propofol infusion syndrome is not associated with Nephropathy

Propofol infusion syndrome is a rare but lethal syndrome seen when the dose of propofol infusion is greater than 4 mg/kg/hour for 48 hours or longer. It is common in children and critically ill adults.

  • Clinical Features:
    • Acute refractory bradycardia leading to asystole in the presence of one or more of the following:
      • Metabolic acidosis (base deficit >10 mmol/L)
      • Rhabdomyolysis
      • Hyperlipidemia
      • Enlarged or fatty liver
      • Other features include cardiomyopathy with acute cardiac failure, skeletal myopathy, hyperkalemia, hepatomegaly, and lipemia.
  • The symptoms and signs are the results of muscle injury and the release of intracellular toxic contents.
  • It is thought to be due to a defect in mitochondrial metabolism and electron transport chain function.
